text: Patient: My hormone shot. Doctor: I don’t know if you – if you get a hormone shot in January and it’s six months, you won’t need another one until July. So, that April version will just be a PSA check and see how we’re doing Patient: Right. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And maybe some more discussion. Family Member: Because that will be at least his third hormone shot. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: And at some point, everybody’s saying those will stop working or could stop working. Doctor: They could stop working. Um. They will stop working eventually. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I mean, usually, it takes a year or two. But, they will stop eventually. Family Member: Okay.

text: Patient: No. Well some swelling. (pause and ruffling sounds) Doctor: A little bit. No bumps at all up here. No pain, no itching. Patient: No. I noticed some weakness in my right leg. This is December and this is last week – up point five. Doctor: Blood count is good, tab - nothing dramatic – sporadic just below the normal range. So your kidney function goes up and down. So two months hundred at one point six, then it was repeated back down to one and then it was up at one point five. Where did you have your scan last week? Patient: In Hospital A in B___. I have the information and phone number. Doctor: So is G___ a new doctor for you or have you seen him for a while? Patient: No, that was only the second visit. Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem.

text: Patient: Yeah. I - Doctor: Well, I mean, I don’t know. I can find out from the group at Cornell which sounds like at least would be- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Within striking distance for you from, from the east coast. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: How quickly? If you’re eligible, how quickly you could uh- Patient: Sure. Sure. Doctor: You could go on before you uh, I think their trial is a, so it’s called a phase one trial. So what does that mean? So phase one traditionally was uh a dose-finding trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it determines how toxic things were. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So with drugs what will often happen is a patient on a phase one where you came at an early stage you’d get a very low dose, probably too low to have toxicity but too low to be effective. And when you get to the high dose, it might be plenty to be effective but toxic, so you’d always sort of be Goldilocks at the end. Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: Clinical study? Doctor: Yeah it’s a clinical trial a hormonal agent that has at least three clinically shown promising results. Patient: And that would be here? text: Family Member: Right. Doctor: They’re just taking it as uh pay as you go. Uh so we’ve talked before, and I know you have the means to do it. Uh they, so, I’d, I’d work with a group. Doctor: It’s near, it’s in East Germany. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh those two groups have the biggest experience. The guy I know very well is in Bad Berka. Uh I think both groups though will take referrals, and then they take over and make the arrangements for folks to come, put you up, all the things. And the number they quoted me is about fifty-thousand bucks to do it. Um which by American standards, is incredibly cheap, but because you can’t get, take advantage of health insurance, you know. Patient: Yeah. It really is sort of out of pocket. Family Member: But he could do it right away? Doctor: He could potentially. I, I, at least I could contact my contact and find out. I also know the group in Heidelberg. We could find out. Uh the groups here, uh I don’t know the Cornell group and the group at UCLA. I don’t know. Those are trials. text: Patient: I’m not that bad but there is a lot of inconsistency though. Doctor: Right but that’s your body doesn’t do well with inconsistency. It wants to know what’s coming. So if you know for example, you’re just having a hard time sleeping, then just take your Norco at night so that way you can get a good night’s rest. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you know listen at night I’m not bothered I sleep like a rock, then take it when you first get up so that you can function. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Or you get up and it’s tolerable but now it’s the early afternoon, you still have more stuff to do, you’ve got family, you’ve got friends, there’s a barbeque, so take some, just a small amount… Patient: Sure. Doctor: To take the edge off. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So that you can actually enjoy your life. Patient: Sure. Quality has been there. It hasn’t been compromised yet. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: And I understand where you’re

text: Patient: I’m sorry, it also mentioned that Metformin is a cancer fighter. Doctor: Right, there is some evidence which I would call modest. You know in other words it’s not absolutely conclusive, but it’s not you know terribly weak either um that , at prostate cancer specifically, and other cancers in general, there might be a direct anti tumor effect Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Now uhm I am somewhat convinced by the data. Uhm the perfect way to prove that, and this may never happen, is to actually design a trial. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Where you take people that already have a diagnosis of prostate cancer – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: - and then you randomize it. In other words, you flip a coin. You give half of them a specified dose of Metformin and you give the other half a placebo immunotherapy. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then at the end of the day you look at the outcomes and you see are the recurrence rates you know slowed down less in the patients that receive the Metformin or alternatively our prevention rates that with time those that don’t receive the Metformin. The - the type of studies that have suggested that Metformin is beneficial, the so-called epidemiological studies. In other words, given the retrospectives, where they take a series of patients – Patient: Got it. Doctor: - and they go back and ask them based on questionnaires Were you taking Metformin and when did you start and how long? What was the reason for being on it? Patient: Yes.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
